text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in the Swedish papers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Prime Minister Goran Persson and the leader of the government's informal cooperation partner the Centre Party, Olof Johansson, vow they will stand as joint guarantors for costs of phasing out Sweden's nuclear reactors. They say in a joint column that will together attack unemployment in the country.

- Sweden's Bonnier family may have to part with some of their media holdings, Culture Minister Marita Ulvskog says, to weaken their dominance within Swedish media. The Bonniers announced on Tuesday they were moving into Swedish domestic televsion.

- Closing down Barseback nuclear power station will cost at least 20 billion crowns, says Nils Yngvesson, the board head of the power plant's owner, Swedish power utility Sydkraft AB. Sydkraft is against the government's plans, announced this week, to start phasing out nuclear power in Sweden.
- Taxation Minister Thomas Ostros says households, not the electricity intensive industry, will have to pick up the eventual bill for the closing of Sweden's nuclear power plants.

- Culture Minister Marita Ulvskog would like to stop the Bonnier family's move into television to prevent the family from becoming too dominant within the country's media. The Bonniers took their first step into domestic Swedish television when the media company they control, Tidnings AB Marieberg, bought a 16.7 percent stake in TV4 on Tuesday.

- Swedish brokerage Alfred Berg calculates which Swedish companies would become winners if Stockholm's bid for the 2004 summer Olympic games was successful. Architecture and consultancy firm FFNS, consultancy firm VBB and construction and real estate company JM are among those set to reap profits from the event if it were held here.

- Stockholmers are more industrious than other Swedes. The take less in state benefits than their countrymen and pay more in taxes, statistics show. Creative people move to the capital from all around the country. Half of Sweden's computer experts work in the region as well as 40 percent of the nation's civil engineers.

- The announcement that merger talks between Swedish bank's S-E-Banken and state-controlled Nordbanken fuelled rises in Danish bank share prices. Market players are speculating that S-E-Banken will try to link with Unibank or Jyske Bank.
